section.title: Simple Discount
section.p: In , we skipped simple discount. It was not necessary until now. U.S. T-Bills quote their rate as a simple discount rate (as opposed to Canadian T-Bills, which quote simple interest rates). This is sensible since simple interest (and discount) is used over short periods of time, and T-Bills reach maturity in less than one year.
Recall that simple interest is linear. We have A(t) = A(0)(1+\iota t). Similarly, simple discount is linear. Since discount is backward-looking, we would like to find a(t) so that A(0) = A(t)a(t).

introduction.p: We'll start with an example. Suppose Konstantin Avdonin borrows 100 for a 6-month period with an annual simple interest rate of \iota = 9\%.

task.p: By linearity, what is the rate applied over a 6-month period?
For simple interest, we multiply the six-month rate by A(0) and add to A(0) to get A(1/2). Find this amount.
Generalize what you did for Konstantin and derive the simple interest formula for A(t).

introduction.p: Now we will construct a formula for simple discount. Remember that we are looking for A(0) assuming we know A(t) (discount is backward-looking).
We will start with another example. Ming Chen borrows A(0), and repays 100 after 3 months. The annual simple discount rate is 4\%.

task.p: By linearity, what is the rate applied over a 3-month period?
For simple discount, we multiply the 3-month rate by A(1/4), adding the result to A(0) to get A(1/4). Use this idea to write an equation, and solve the equation for A(0).
Generalize what you did for Ming and derive the simple discount formula for A(0).

statement.p: Suppose a loan of 1000 is to be repaid in six months, subject to simple discount. Find the amount borrowed if the annual simple discount rate is 2.5%.
Suppose a loan of 1000 is repaid after one quarter, subject to simple discount. Find the annual simple discount rate if the amount borrowed was 997.50.
Russel Jackson borrows 462.60 to be repaid in 9 months at an annual simple discount rate of 10%. How much is paid back at the end of the term?
Summarize the similarities and differences between simple interest and simple discount.
